title: 113_s1428
content: The "Prepare, Ready, Equip, and Prevent Areas at Risk of Emergency Wildfires Act of 2013" or the "PREPARE Act of 2013" is an amendment to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act, specifically addressing wildfire mitigation by adding section 203A. The "PREPARE Act of 2013" establishes definitions for terms like Administrator, community wildfire protection plan, local mitigation plan, and State mitigation plan. It also sets up a grant program for wildfire mitigation and preparedness in States. The "PREPARE Act of 2013" establishes a grant program for wildfire mitigation and preparedness in States. Grants can be used for reducing fuel load, improving personnel and organization preparedness, investing in equipment like air tankers, preventing damage from runoff and floods, and other wildfire mitigation activities as determined by the State Governor. The "PREPARE Act of 2013" establishes a grant program for wildfire mitigation and preparedness in States. States are eligible for assistance if their grant ratio meets certain criteria based on declarations received in the previous 10 years. The grant ratio for States under the "PREPARE Act of 2013" is determined by the total number of declarations for a grant in the US over the past 10 years and the State population ratio based on the most recent Census data. The grant ratio for States under the "PREPARE Act of 2013" is determined by the total number of declarations for a grant in the US over the past 10 years, divided by the population of the United States. The President may waive this requirement if a State files a petition and demonstrates significant environmental concerns. The "PREPARE Act of 2013" allows States to receive funds for wildfire prevention if they show increased risk of catastrophic wildfires due to environmental changes. Governors can allocate funds to counties, municipalities, or other entities with wildfire protection or mitigation plans. Assistance criteria are based on the design of these plans. The President will prioritize awarding grants to States with high need for assistance based on scientific data, those providing matching non-Federal funds, and those who have efficiently used previous grant funds for wildfire mitigation and preparedness activities. The President will prioritize awarding grants to States with high need for assistance based on scientific data, matching non-Federal funds, and efficient use of previous grant funds for wildfire mitigation and preparedness activities. States requesting grants must submit an application demonstrating publicly available State mitigation plans and meeting other specified requirements. The State must provide matching funds equal to at least 50% of the Federal funds for wildfire protection grants. Counties or municipalities eligible for funds must have a wildfire protection plan. States receiving grants must submit a public report on fund usage within a year. The President will allocate $20-30 million from the National Predisaster Mitigation Fund for assistance. The President will allocate $20-30 million from the National Predisaster Mitigation Fund for each fiscal year from 2014 to 2019. This section does not increase appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security.
